awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Practice of Registering Indian Citizens Using Biometric Information
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary     

This award is a doctoral dissertation improvement grant. It supports a study of India's biometric-based registration practices. The study focuses on the tension between the promise of empowerment and the challenges of achieving it by paying close attention to the practices of enrolling citizens into Aadhaar "voluntarily." It also will focus on how various Indian bureaucracies, such as the Public Distribution System (PDS), are using Aadhaar to distribute welfare entitlements of citizens. The results of this study will serve to extend the reach of Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholarship to sites and practices that are key to the emerging real-worldly challenges of using biometrics for citizen empowerment. More broadly, these results will serve as a resource for ongoing deliberations on the extent to which Aadhaar may succeed or fail to mediate state-citizen relationships. In addition, by critically examining the claims of Aadhaar-enabled social inclusion of vulnerable communities, they may also contribute to the design of more inclusive and accountable systems of identification.

Technical Summary    

In this study, the investigators will use a multi-sited study using multiple methods including ethnographic research on the constituencies involved and document analysis examining the technical, legal, and bureaucratic interventions in the deployment of Aadhaar. The investigators will document public engagement with the legitimacy of the government's promises to empower residents through registration in Aadhaar while downplaying concerns about surveillance, and they will document the differential ability to leverage Aadhaar for personal benefits. They will then articulate implications for state identification practices. Those implications will contribute to STS concerns regarding deployment of information infrastructures, the politics of numbers and metrics, and the anthropology of state governance. They will also contribute to the biopolitical turn in infrastructure studies by identifying forms of citizenship that emerge in using biometrics for citizen identification.

por.por_cntn:
Can a state empower its citizens by uniquely identifying them? This question is central to debates about registration of Indian residents in India's biometrics-based national identification project called Aadhaar (translation: Foundation). This research was designed to advance public understanding of biometrics-based bureaucratic practices by examining the tension between the promise of empowerment and the challenges of achieving it by producing an ethnography of the legal, administrative, and technological controversies over the design, implementation, and use of Aadhaar. The Indian government is proselytizing Aadhaar enrollment by emphasizing the benefits of being made accountable to state sponsored programs. However, critics express skepticism not only by invoking potential for surveillance enabled by Aadhaar, but also by articulating state accountability as a promise that goes beyond unique identification. The research specifically focused on distinctive forms of citizenship that emerge in relation to the differential ability of residents in leveraging Aadhaar to make social welfare claims. Its aim was to extend the reach of Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholarship to sites and practices that are key to the emerging real-worldly challenges of using biometrics for citizen empowerment.

This research led to the development of a conceptual framework for Seeing like an (information) infrastructure. It identified mechanisms through which information infrastructures see their users (here, citizens) and described the complexities of configuring them in the case of Aadhaar. We followed the mundane practices and prosaic failures which shape and characterize the efforts of the Indian bureaucracy to see, know, and manage its 'users' (here, citizens) through Aadhaar. With the increasing proliferation of information systems and associated tools and techniques for data analytics and machine learning in governance, knowing citizens has become a matter of managing and interpreting their data records. For Aadhaar, the work on such records begins with establishing a unique data record for every Indian resident through biometrics. Identifying citizens, thus, turns into a problem of locating their data record in various databases of government services. Citizen identity emerges as a reasonable mapping between their lives and data records. In the era of digital governance, a state comes to know its citizens and citizens come to experience the state through data records. These data records, however, represent citizens at a particular resolution. 

Resolution, as a visual attribute, refers to the degree of clarity of an image on a computer screen or optical instrument, expressed as a matter of scale or degree: the lower the resolution, the less detailed the image becomes. Analogously, certain systems and combinations of data can provide more comprehensive pictures of users than others. While absence of representative data renders users and their activities less visible to an information infrastructure, the presence of granular data makes them more so; the former engenders user representations at a lower resolution than the latter. Importantly, resolution is also a matter of adjustment and scale: add, improve, or cross-reference data, and resolution increases (rather like the zoom and focus of a camera lens); subtract, degrade, or de-link, and resolution declines. Different user resolutions create different problems: higher resolutions pose privacy and surveillance risks; lower resolutions run the risk of marginalization and abjection.

This research reveals how the tensions within the mechanisms of achieving resolution -- and the specific information infrastructures through which they are operationalized -- are central to both the peril and promise of the state-citizen relationships. On the one hand, understanding these mechanisms is important, since more knowledge about how to see citizens through data is highly valuable for data-driven state bureaucracies confronted by the complexity of managing them. For instance, which data categories should be mandatory for registration and how should accountability be distributed in circulation and interpretation of citizen records as different parts of these records are managed by different bureaucracies are integral questions in understanding the workings of a data-driven state. On the other hand, these mechanisms offer a toolkit for citizens to understand how they are represented in the workings of the state and concomitant challenges of claiming citizenship rights. Here questions of how citizens are rendered residual and how they work with and around prescribed data categories to secure their representation offers a generative site to describe their political, social, and material work to (re)claim and maintain standing as citizens in the eyes of the state.

Seeing like an infrastructure, thus, is at the very heart of the social and moral problem of governing a diverse population digitally: social, because making up and interpreting population as a database requires so much work, organization, and discipline; moral, because using data records to represent citizens inevitably involves responding to demands of fairness, accountability, and justice. The dissertation and publications resulting from this research provide a window into the scope and complexity of using data citizen records in matters of governance.
